source.document_id: Robot assisted bronchoscopy for pulmonary lesion diagnosis

metadata.title: Robot-assisted bronchoscopy for pulmonary lesion diagnosis: results from the initial multicenter experience

sections.abstract: Background: The Robotic Endoscopic System (Auris Health, Inc., Redwood City, CA) has the potential to overcome several limitations of contemporary guided-bronchoscopic technologies for the diagnosis of lung lesions. Our objective is to report on the initial post-marketing feasibility, safety and diagnostic yield of this technology. Methods: We retrospectively reviewed data on consecutive cases in which robot-assisted bronchoscopy was used to sample lung lesions at four centers in the US (academic and community) from June 15th, 2018 to December 15th, 2018. Results: One hundred and sixty-seven lesions in 165 patients were included in the analysis, with an average follow-up of 185 ± 55 days. The average size of target lesions was 25.0 ± 15.0 mm. Seventy-one percent were located in the peripheral third of the lung. Pneumothorax and airway bleeding occurred in 3.6 and 2.4% cases, respectively. Navigation was successful in 88.6% of cases. Tissue samples were successfully obtained in 98.8%. The diagnostic yield estimates ranged from 69.1 to 77% assuming the cases of biopsy-proven inflammation without any follow-up information (N = 13) were non-diagnostic and diagnostic, respectively. The yield was 81.5, 71.7 and 26.9% for concentric, eccentric and absent r-EBUS views, respectively. Diagnostic yield was not affected by lesion size, density, lobar location or centrality. Conclusions: RAB implementation in community and academic centers is safe and feasible, with an initial diagnostic yield of 69.1-77% in patients with lung lesions that require diagnostic bronchoscopy. Comparative trials with the existing bronchoscopic technologies are needed to determine cost-effectiveness of this technology.
sections.methods: We retrospectively reviewed consecutive cases using robot-assisted bronchoscopy (RAB) with the Monarch Endoscopy Platform (Auris Health, Inc.) for diagnosis of lung lesions at four US centers from June 15, 2018 to December 15, 2018. Inclusion: adults ≥18 years, acceptable for elective bronchoscopy under general anesthesia, with pulmonary lesions requiring bronchoscopic biopsy (suspected primary lung cancer per guidelines, suspected recurrence/progression, lesions in patients with history of extrathoracic malignancy, or suspected mycobacterial/fungal infection requiring tissue diagnosis). Exclusion: obvious endobronchial lesion easily biopsied by conventional bronchoscopy. Endpoints: device/procedure-related complications (pneumothorax of any size, significant airway bleeding requiring management with conventional bronchoscope, respiratory failure within 24 h), successful navigation (eccentric or concentric r-EBUS view or diagnostic tissue), and diagnostic yield (final pathology diagnostic without subsequent discordant diagnosis/progression; cases treated for cancer without pathologic diagnosis considered non-diagnostic). General anesthesia with endotracheal tube; standard inspection bronchoscopy performed; EBUS-TBNA when indicated prior to RAB. The robotic bronchoscope comprises an outer sheath (6.0 mm) and inner scope (4.2 mm), with EM field generator; r-EBUS used for confirmation; no CBCT. Biopsy tools advanced through 2.1 mm working channel under fluoroscopy. Statistical analysis: chi-squared tests for associations; multivariable logistic regression adjusting for lesion location, centrality, density, size, bronchus sign, and r-EBUS view; two-tailed p<0.05 significant; Stata 14.1.
sections.results: A total of 167 lesions in 165 patients were biopsied; average follow-up 185 ± 55 days. Mean lesion size 25.0 ± 15.0 mm; 70.7% peripheral; bronchus sign present in 106/167 (63.5%); 125/167 (74.9%) solid. Navigation successful in 148/167 (88.6%). r-EBUS detected target in 141/167 (84.4%): concentric 81/141 (57.5%), eccentric 60/141 (42.5%). Tissue samples obtained in 161/165 (97.6%) patients; 4 (2.4%) cases without samples (1 software failure, 3 unsuccessful navigation). Overall diagnostic yield ranged 69.1-77%, depending on handling of 13 inflammation-only cases without follow-up. Diagnostic yield by r-EBUS view: concentric 66/81 (81.5%), eccentric 43/60 (71.7%), no view 7/26 (26.9%); p<0.001. Yield higher with bronchus sign 83/106 (78.3%) vs 54.1% without; p=0.001. Yield not different by lesion density (solid 86/125 [68.8%] vs ground glass 12/17 [70.6%]; p=0.74), central vs peripheral (73.5% vs 67.8%; p=0.47), or size (<10 mm 5/11 [45.5%], 10-30 mm 74/108 [68.5%], >30 mm 37/48 [77.1%]; p=0.11). Multivariable logistic regression: bronchus sign OR 2.3 (95% CI 1.0-5.3; p=0.04); r-EBUS view vs no view: eccentric OR 7.4 (95% CI 2.4-22.9; p<0.001), concentric OR 10.0 (95% CI 3.2-31.1; p<0.001). Complications: pneumothorax 6/167 (3.6%), chest tube in 4/167 (2.4%); significant airway bleeding 4/167 (2.4%), controlled with cold saline; no respiratory failure or deaths.

population.text: Adults undergoing robot-assisted bronchoscopy for diagnosis of pulmonary lesions at 4 US centers
inclusion_criteria: Acceptable candidate for elective bronchoscopy under general anesthesia
Pulmonary lesions suspected of primary lung cancer requiring bronchoscopic biopsy per guidelines
History of lung cancer with new or growing lung lesions requiring tissue diagnosis
Pulmonary lesions in patients with a history of extrathoracic malignancy requiring tissue diagnosis
Suspected mycobacterial or fungal pulmonary lesions requiring tissue diagnosis prior to therapy
exclusion_criteria: Obvious endobronchial lesion on inspection bronchoscopy that can be easily biopsied using conventional white light bronchoscopy

intervention.text: Robot-assisted bronchoscopy (Monarch Endoscopy Platform, Auris Health, Inc.)
intervention.details: General anesthesia with endotracheal tube; inspection bronchoscopy; EBUS-TBNA when indicated; robotic bronchoscope with 6.0 mm sheath and 4.2 mm inner scope advanced to peripheral airways using EM navigation; r-EBUS used for confirmation; biopsies performed via 2.1 mm working channel under fluoroscopy; no CBCT used.

retrieval.summary_tldr: In 165 patients (167 lesions), robot-assisted bronchoscopy achieved 88.6% navigation success, 69.1-77% diagnostic yield, with pneumothorax in 3.6% (chest tube 2.4%) and significant bleeding in 2.4%.
retrieval.clinical_relevance: Early multicenter post-marketing experience suggests robot-assisted bronchoscopy is feasible and safe with diagnostic yield comparable to or higher than contemporary guided bronchoscopy; higher yield with bronchus sign and concentric r-EBUS view.
